Gautham Adamane Pallathadka
Profile
I am a doctoral student at Johns Hopkins University, where I'm passionately pursuing research into Type-Ia supernova progenitors to help unravel the mysteries of stellar binary evolution. Broadly, I am also interested in the intricate history of binary stars, with a specific interest in the mass transfer phases, especially the complex and often chaotic common envelope phase, as well as the fascinating study of post-common envelope binaries. Beyond physics, I am captivated by all kinds of messy topics, and enjoy the challenge of finding gems within chaotic systems.
Education

Bachelor of Science and Master of Science in Physics

2016 - 2021 at Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IITM), Chennai, India

Master of Arts in Physics

2021 - 2023 at Johns Hopkins University (JHU), Baltimore, U.S.A

Doctor of Philosophy in Astrophysics

2021 - 2027 (expected) at Johns Hopkins University (JHU), Baltimore, U.S.A

Experience

Research Internship at Raman Research Institute (RRI), Bangalore, India

Advisor: Prof. Shiv Sethi (2018-2020)

I modeled charged, interacting dark matter models and implemented it into the cosmological Boltzmann equations. I then simulated the impact of these new models on the evolution of our universe, and performed Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analysis to place bounds on possible parameter space of charged dark matter models.

Link to the publication: Cosmological implications of electromagnetically interacting dark matter: milli-charged particles and atoms with singly and doubly charged dark matter.

Research Internship at Laboratoire d’Annecy-le-Vieux de Physique Théorique (LAPTh), Annecy, France

Advisor: Dr. Francesca Calore (2019-2021)

I used a model of axion like particle (ALP), that can morph into photons, to explain oscillations observed in gamma-ray spectra of Pulsars. I leveraged the faster execution of C++ and community developed physics packages in Python, and developed an efficient code to simulate the photon-ALP interaction by integrating Python to run with C++. Using this I performed maximum likelihood analysis to place constraints on ALP models.

Link to the publication: Reconciling hints on axion-like-particles from high-energy gamma rays with stellar bounds.

Master's thesis project at Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IITM), Chennai, India

Advisor: Prof. Dawood Kothawala (2020-2021)

I studied particle production in curved space using worldline instanton formalism. I explored the application of instanton formalism to study particle production due to complex scalar fields in de-Sitter spacetime, and reproduced the form for Schwinger particle production in de-Sitter spacetime.

PhD at Johns Hopkins University (JHU), Baltimore, U.S.A

Advisor: Prof. Nadia L. Zakamska (2022-Present)

  • 6+ years experience in Python
  • Limited experience in C++
